content.question: On an oblate spheroid representing the Earth’s shape 1 minute of arc along the…

options.A: meridian at low latitudes measures a greater distance than 1 minute of arc along the meridian at high latitudes.
options.B: meridian at 0°N/S measures the same distance as 1 minute of arc at 90°N/S.
options.C: Equator measures the same distance as 1 minute of arc along the meridian at a latitude of 45°N/S.
options.D: Equator measures a greater distance than 1 minute of arc along the meridian at a latitude of 45°N/S.

key_points: The base of D is referring to 1' of arc along a Meridian versus 1' of arc along the Equator
The true shape of the Earth is an Oblate Spheroid, "Oblate" referring to it's slightly oblong appearance, "Spheroid" meaning that it is almost a sphere, but not quite
One of the most important things to remember about the Earth's shape is that it is only very slightly oblate
learning.explanation: The base of D is referring to 1' of arc along a Meridian versus 1' of arc along the Equator. The true shape of the Earth is an Oblate Spheroid, "Oblate" referring to it's slightly oblong appearance, "Spheroid" meaning that it is almost a sphere, but not quite. One of the most important things to remember about the Earth's shape is that it is only very slightly oblate. The diameter from the North Pole to the South Pole (the shortest diameter) is approximately 12,714 km (6,860 NM). The equatorial diameter (the longest diameter) is approximately 12,756 km (6,883 NM). This is not a big difference, but it does make the Earth not quite a sphere. Therefore: The polar diameter of 6,860 NM produces a circumference of 21,554 NM, each minute of arc being equal to 0.998 NM The equatorial diameter of 6,883 NM produces a circumference of 21,626 NM, each minute of arc being equal to 1.001 NM

content.question:
Given the following information, what heading correction is required to proceed directly to position B?
Planned track from A to B: 284°(T)
Planned distance between A and B: 50 NM
Planned ground speed: 132 kt
Time between A and fix position: 10 minutes
At fix position: 4 NM right-off course and 2 NM behind DR position

key_points: The planned distance covered in 10 min after position A is: 132 kt x 10/60 hr = 22 NM
So, the fix position (2 NM behind DR position) will be: 22 NM - 2 NM = 20 NM from A
Using your Flight/Nav computer, the corrections that must be made to the heading are: Degrees to parallel: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance travelled, 20 NM inner scale
learning.explanation: The planned distance covered in 10 min after position A is: 132 kt x 10/60 hr = 22 NM. So, the fix position (2 NM behind DR position) will be: 22 NM - 2 NM = 20 NM from A. Using your Flight/Nav computer, the corrections that must be made to the heading are: Degrees to parallel: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance travelled, 20 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to parallel: 12° (12) on outer scale. Degrees to intercept position B: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance to go, 30 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to intercept: 8° (12) on outer scale. Thus, the total heading correction to proceed directly to position B is: 12° + 8° = 20°. And since the deviation is to the right, the heading correction must be to the left.

content.question: Where on the Earth does the sunrise occur earlier and earlier every day?

key_points: If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis
The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year
The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic
learning.explanation: If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year. The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic. At the Equator, the length of the day and night varies very little and then only due to the differences between the mean solar day (which is used for time keeping) and the apparent time kept by the Sun. Hence, at the Equator the sunrise will always be close to 0600 LMT and the sunset close to 1800 LMT. At the spring and autumn equinoxes, the time of sunrise and the time of sunset is approximately the same at all latitudes (within a few minutes of 0600 LMT and 1800 LMT respectively). Thus, at mid-latitudes, such as 33°N, the sunrise occurs earlier and earlier every day.

The groundspeed for this track is approximately 89 kt. Refer to figure.
An aircraft is flying according the flight log at the Annex. After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 3 NM North of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position. To reach destination B from this position the TH should be:

key_points: A ground speed of 130 kt will result in a distance after 15 minutes of 32
5 NM
learning.explanation: A ground speed of 130 kt will result in a distance after 15 minutes of 32.5 NM. 32.5 NM + 2.5 NM (ahead of DR position) = 35 NM. Drift = arc tan (3 NM / 35 NM) = 5°. The distance from our actual position to B = 50 NM – 35 NM = 15 NM. Arc tan (3 NM / 15 NM) = 11°. The correction angle to apply on our heading, to fly a course directly to B, is 5° + 11° = 16°. Heading to the West and drift to the North = right of course, so the correction has to be applied to the left. 275° - 16° = 259° (approximately 258°).

content.question: An aircraft is flying inbound a VOR along radial 310° and experiences a drift of 10°R. If the Groundspeed is 415 kt, the True airspeed is 480 kt and variation is 7°W, calculate the wind direction (M) and speed.

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from heading to track The aircraft flies along the radial 310° inbound a VOR, then its magnetic track is: 310° - 180° = 130°M
And since it drifts by 10oR, then its magnetic heading is: 130°M - 10o = 120oM
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from heading to track The aircraft flies along the radial 310° inbound a VOR, then its magnetic track is: 310° - 180° = 130°M. And since it drifts by 10oR, then its magnetic heading is: 130°M - 10o = 120oM. For this question using your Navigation/Flight computer, apply the following steps: Place the centre dot over the TAS 480 kt. Set the Magnetic heading 120o under the True Index. Put a mark where the 10o starboard drift and the Groundspeed 415 kt coincide. Rotate the circular bezel until the mark you have made is exactly below the centre dot on the 0o drift line. The magnetic wind direction is shown under the True Index 075o (M). The wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot and the value under the mark: 480 kt - 380 kt = 100 kt. Therefore, the magnetic wind direction and speed is: 075°(M)/100 kt. E6-B Flight Computer Procedure: We are given a GS of 415 kt and TAS of 480 kt, however the wind speed on the slide reaches a maximum of about 264 kt, we can still use the E6-B flight computer following these steps: If your E6-B flight computer includes a high-speed side, you can skip the following steps and proceed directly to the procedure below using the given GS and TAS values. Divide the GS and TAS by 5: GS: 415 kt / 5 = 83 kt TAS: 480 kt / 5 = 96 kt Now, with GS = 83 kt and TAS = 96 kt, proceed as follows: Multiply the calculated (steps below) wind velocity by 5. Calculation of Magnetic Wind Direction and Velocity: Position the slide until the ring aligns with the speed arc corresponding to the Ground Speed (83 kt). Rotate the transparent disk to align the Magnetic Track (130°) under the TRUE INDEX. Determine the Wind Correction Angle (WCA): With a Drift angle of 10° to the right, WCA = 10° left. With the ring on the Ground Speed (83 kt) arc, mark the point where the 10° left WCA intersects the True Airspeed (96 kt) arc. Rotate the transparent disk until the mark aligns with the centerline, ABOVE the ring, between the ring and the TRUE INDEX. Count the lines between the ring and the mark to determine the Wind Velocity. In this case, with the ring on the 83 kt arc and the mark on the 103 kt arc, Wind Velocity = 100 kt (103 - 83 = 20, 20 x 5 = 100). Read the Magnetic Wind Direction under the TRUE INDEX. In this case, the value is 075°, resulting in Magnetic Wind Direction = 075°.

content.question:
Given:
True Track 300°
Drift 8°R
Variation 10°W
Deviation -4°
Calculate the compass heading.

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading. The heading is the direction in witch the the aircraft’s nose is pointing for. True Track is 300º with drift 8º R, means that TT is right of Heading 292º (T). True heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass heading (C) 292º 10ºW 302º 4ºW 306º

content.question: An island is observed to be 15° to the left of the aircraft’s longitudinal axis. The aircraft heading is 120°M, variation 17°W. The true bearing from the aircraft to the island is…

key_points: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station
QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station
NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE
learning.explanation: Relative bearing is the clockwise angle from the fore/aft axis of the aircraft to the station. QDR Aircraft’s Magnetic Bearing from the station (Radial); QDM Aircraft’s Magnetic bearing to the station; QTE Aircraft’s True Bearing from the station; QUJ Aircraft’s True Track to the station. NOTE: QDM is the reciprocal of QDR; QUJ is the reciprocal of QTE. Converting a Relative Bearing (RBI) into a True Bearing: Apply aircraft variation to the magnetic heading to get true heading. Add relative bearing to true heading in order to obtain true bearing TO the station If the answer comes to more than 360°(T), subtract 360. Take the reciprocal in order to get the True Bearing to plot FROM the station. QUJ = RBI + True Heading QTE = RBI + True Heading +180º To obtain a True Heading from the Magnetic Heading: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 103º 17ºW 120º The relative bearing is always measured clockwise from the nose of the aircraft, 15º left is the same as RBI 345º. Aircraft’s True Track to the island, QUJ = 345º + 103º = 448º 448º - 360º = 88º (T)

content.question: A pilot during the pre-flight planning procedure uses an aeronautical chart to find the magnetic variation. Which statement is correct regarding the magnetic variation at a specific position?

options.A: Although the magnetic poles move over time, local variation remains constant.
options.B: Volcanic activity causes magnetic variation to increase, any given geographic area.
options.C: Magnetic variation changes over time, due to displacement of magnetic materials in the earth.
options.D: The rise of mean sea level due to global warming causes magnetic variation to increase or decrease.

key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero
Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing. Since, the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. The pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

content.question:
An aircraft approaches runway 24 of Ryan airfield. The tower gives a wind of 260°/26 kt.The magnetic variation is 12°E. According to the airport chart the direction of runway 24 is 238°.
Calculate the head/tailwind component.

key_points: Wind directions True or Magnetic? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction
Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic
Wind information given by the tower is already magnetic and the runway is also magnetic, no need to apply variation
learning.explanation: Wind directions True or Magnetic? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction. Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic. Wind information given by the tower is already magnetic and the runway is also magnetic, no need to apply variation. The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. Head/Tail wind component = Wind Speed x cosine (Relative Bearing) Crosswind component = Wind Speed x sine (Relative Bearing) Wind information given by the tower is already magnetic and the runway is also magnetic, no need to apply variation. Head/Tail wind component = 26 x cosine (260º - 238º) = 24 kts Headwind ou tailwind ? visualize the track of the aircraft and from where is the wind coming from. Departing runway 24 with a wind blowing from 260º, the wind will mainly act as a headwind.

content.question: You have to determine the wind for a flight from VOR 1 to VOR 2 at FL55 with an OAT of +10°C. You passed VOR 1 at 12:10 UTC and arrived overhead VOR 2 at 12:18 UTC. Your magnetic heading is 005° and the calibrated airspeed is 145 kt. The distance between both VORs is 25 NM and the magnetic track from VOR 1 to VOR 2 is 355°. Calculate the wind direction (M) and speed:

key_points: Convert CAS into TAS (CRP5 method): (1) In the "Airspeed" window, align 5500 ft with OAT = +10ºC; (2) On the inner arc, look for CAS 145 kt and read a result of approximately 160 kt TAS
Calculate the Ground Speed: Ground Speed = Distance / Time Ground Speed = 25 NM / 8 min = 187
5 kt Determine Drift: There is a 10º difference between the track and the heading, which means that drift = 10º
learning.explanation: Convert CAS into TAS (CRP5 method): (1) In the "Airspeed" window, align 5500 ft with OAT = +10ºC; (2) On the inner arc, look for CAS 145 kt and read a result of approximately 160 kt TAS. Calculate the Ground Speed: Ground Speed = Distance / Time Ground Speed = 25 NM / 8 min = 187.5 kt Determine Drift: There is a 10º difference between the track and the heading, which means that drift = 10º. Track is lower than heading, meaning it's a left drift (10ºL). Determine W/V (CRP5 method): 1. Set Magnetic Heading (005ºM) under "True Index" 2. Place centre dot over TAS (160 kts) 3. Mark the point where drift (10ºL) and GS (187.5 kt) meet. 4. Rotate the wind computer until mark is below TAS. 5. Check wind direction under "True Index" (132º) 6. Count down from TAS to obtain wind speed (160 - 119 = 41 kt) => W/V = 132(ºM)/41 kt, which is very close to 133° / 41 kt.

content.question: What is the definition of the Geodetic Longitude?

options.A: The distance between the plane of the meridian that passes through a point on the surface of the ellipsoid and the plane of the anti-meridian.
options.B: The distance between the plane of the meridian that passes through a point on the surface of the ellipsoid and the plane of the prime meridian.
options.C: The angle between the plane of the meridian that passes through a point on the surface of the ellipsoid and the plane of the prime meridian.
options.D: The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the anti-meridian of the point.

key_points: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes
Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane
There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England
learning.explanation: Latitude and longitude are the grid lines you see on globes. Longitude is the angle in the equatorial plane. There is no natural reference for longitude, but the zero line, called the "prime meridian", is taken, by convention, as the line through Greenwich England. For a spherical Earth, latitude and longitude are angles seen from the center of the Earth and only for the longitude is the exactly the same as for an ellipsoid Earth. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic longitude is defined as "The angular distance between the prime meridian and another meridian passing through a point on the Earth's surface" or "The angle in the equatorial plane between the line a that connects the Earth's centre with the prime meridian and the line b that connects the centre with the meridian on which the point lies". Because the vertex of the angle is the centre of the Earth, the same as for geocentric longitude, the value is the same for both types of longitude.

content.question: An aircraft when tracking inbound with a TAS of 150 kt onto a VOR on the 325° radial, experiences a drift of 10° right. The same aircraft after departure with a TAS of 150 kt tracks outbound on the 075° radial of the same VOR, experiencing a drift of 10° right. What is the wind velocity and direction (T°), if magnetic variation is 8° East?

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
When tracking inbound on Radial 325°, then its magnetic track is: 325°M - 180° = 145°M
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). When tracking inbound on Radial 325°, then its magnetic track is: 325°M - 180° = 145°M. Thus, its true track is: 145°M + 8° = 153°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 10° right, its heading is: 153°T - 10° = 143°T. When tracking outbound on Radial 075°, then its magnetic track is 075°M and its true track: 075°M + 8 = 083°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 10° right, its heading is: 083°T - 10° = 073°T. A method to assess the wind is to use the drift on different headings, known as multi-drift wind method: Place the centre dot over TAS 150 kt and put true heading 143°T under the True Index. Draw a line down the 10° right drift. Now put the next heading 073°T under the True Index and draw a line down the 10° right drift again. The point where the two drift lines intersect is the end of the wind vector. Rotate the disc until the intersection of the two drift lines is immediately under the centre dot on the 0° drift line. Read off the wind direction below the True Index as 028°T. And the wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot (150) and the value under the drift lines intersection (118): 150 kt - 118 kt = 32 kt. Thus, the wind velocity and direction (T°) is 028°/32 kt.

Given the following information, calculate the True Heading (TH) and TAS:

GS: 123 kt

key_points: Using the Flight Computer: (1) Set the centre dot over the arc marked 100; (2) Set Wind Direction (213º) under True Index; (3) Mark wind Velocity (21 kt) up from center point – over 121 kt; (4) Set True Track (321º) under True Index; (5) Move the slide until the centre dot is over the ground speed arc – 123 kt; (6) You can read the True Airspeed where the end of the line falls – in this case, 118 kt; (7) The wind correction angle (WCA) reads between center line and wind velocity mark – approximately 10ºL
Wind correction angle = 10ºL (-) True Heading = True Track - WCA = 321º - 10º = 311º

content.question: Compass deviation is defined as the angle between..

options.D: the horizontal and the total intensity of the Earth’s magnetic field.

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

content.question:
While proceeding en route, after half the distance between two waypoints, the aircraft’s position is 3 NM left of the desired track. The total distance between the two waypoints is 120 NM.
Using the 1 sin 60 rule and for the purpose of reaching the active waypoint, the heading should be changed by…

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (3/60) x 60 = 3º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (3/60) x 60 = 3º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 3º + 3º = 6º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

content.question: An aircraft took off at 13:58 and passed a fix 59 NM from the starting point at 14:29. The distance left to the destination is 78 NM and the GS is said to be constant along the flight. When will the aircraft arrive at the destination?

learning.explanation: (1) Calculate the Ground Speed for the first leg: Ground Speed = Distance / Flight time Flight Time = 14 h 29 - 13 h 58 = 31 min Ground Speed = (59 NM / 31 min) x 60 min Ground Speed = 114 kt (2) Calculate time to complete the second leg (78 NM): Flight time = Distance / Ground Speed Flight time = 78 NM / 114 kt = 41 min (3) ETA at destination: 14 h 29 min + 41 min = 15 h 10 min

content.question:
Given the following information, using trigonometry, calculate the headwind component, to the nearest full knot.
Runway: 14
Surface wind (from the Tower): 200°/20 kt
Variation: 20°E

key_points: When resolving the wind into head/tailwind and crosswind components, the mathematically correct way to do this, is to apply trigonometry
For this question: The Crosswind component (XWC) is: Wind speed x Sin of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 20 kt x Sin 60° = 17 kt
The Headwind component (HWC) is: Wind speed x Cos of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 20 kt x Cos 60° = 10 kt
learning.explanation: When resolving the wind into head/tailwind and crosswind components, the mathematically correct way to do this, is to apply trigonometry. For this question: The Crosswind component (XWC) is: Wind speed x Sin of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 20 kt x Sin 60° = 17 kt. The Headwind component (HWC) is: Wind speed x Cos of the Angle difference between Rwy and Wind direction = 20 kt x Cos 60° = 10 kt. NOTE: Both wind and runway directions are magnetic, thus you don't have to apply any variation.

What will be the revised ETA (to the nearest minute) overhead turning point B in the following situation? Assume that all other conditions remain unchanged.
Planned ETA over turning point B: 14:14.
Planned distance from turning A to turning point B: 43 NM.
Planned distance from turning A to check feature X: 10 NM.
Actual time overhead check feature X: 1 minute 15 seconds late

key_points: If we are 1 minute 15 seconds (75 seconds) late to the 10 NM point, we can do 75 / 10 and say that we are 7
5 seconds late per nautical mile flown
Then we can multiply this by the number of miles we intend to fly, 7
learning.explanation: If we are 1 minute 15 seconds (75 seconds) late to the 10 NM point, we can do 75 / 10 and say that we are 7.5 seconds late per nautical mile flown. Then we can multiply this by the number of miles we intend to fly, 7.5 x 43, which tells us we will be 322.5 seconds late to turning point B. 322.5 seconds is 5 minutes 22.5 seconds, so we add this on to our expected time at B, to give us a revised ETA of 14:19 when rounded to the nearest minute.

content.question:
You are flying an ILS approach with 12% glideslope. With the following information given:
TAS: 100 kt
Wind compoment: +20 knots
What is the Rate Of Descent?

key_points: Rates Of Descent (RODs) can be calculated using the following formula: ROD = (Glide Angle/60) x (Groundspeed/60) x 6080
You can find the Glide Angle, either: Using your Nav/Flight computer: 1
Place the percentage glideslope 12% over the 10 or 100 (depending on the computer you use) 2
learning.explanation: Rates Of Descent (RODs) can be calculated using the following formula: ROD = (Glide Angle/60) x (Groundspeed/60) x 6080. You can find the Glide Angle, either: Using your Nav/Flight computer: 1. Place the percentage glideslope 12% over the 10 or 100 (depending on the computer you use) 2. Read out the glide angle in degrees, 7.2o, over the 60 marker. OR Applying the formula: Glideslope (%) x 60 / 100 = 12% x 60 / 100 = 7.2o Groundspeed is: TAS + Wind component = 100 kt + 20 kt = 120 kt. Thus, ROD = (7.2/60) x (120/60) x 6080 = 1460 fpm, which is very close to 1440 fpm. An alternative method is: 1. For a 3o glideslope angle only, the following formula states: ROD = 5 x GS = 5 x 120 = 600 fpm. 2. Thus, for a 7.2o glideslope angle, the ROD will be: 600 fpm x 7.2o / 3o = 1440 fpm.

content.question:
Given the following information, what would be the average groundspeed used to plan a climb from MSL (QNH 1013 hPa) to FL270?
CAS: 280 kt
ISA deviation: +5ºC
True Track: 045º
W/V
MSL: 275º(T)/10 kt
5000 ft: 280º(T)/20 kt
10000 ft: 300º(T)/20 kt
15000 ft: 310º(T)/45 kt
20000 ft: 310º(T)/45 kt
25000 ft: 330º(T)/55 kt
30000 ft: 330º(T)/55 kt

key_points: Some questions might give you a range of wind values and TAS values at various altitudes and a true track and ask for the average groundspeed
In these cases, the TAS and W/V to use on the Flight/Nav computer is as follows: For Climb problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude
For Descent problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude
learning.explanation: Some questions might give you a range of wind values and TAS values at various altitudes and a true track and ask for the average groundspeed. In these cases, the TAS and W/V to use on the Flight/Nav computer is as follows: For Climb problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 2/3 of the cruising altitude. For Descent problems - the TAS and W/V at the altitude 1/2 of the descent altitude. The aircraft climbs from MSL (0 ft) to FL270. The 2/3 of the cruising altitude is at: 0 ft + [2/3 x (27 000)] ft = 18000 ft For the wind velocity at 18 000 ft then, we would usually have to interpolate 3/5ths of the way from 15 000 ft to 20 000 ft, but the winds are the same so no interpolation necessary. We can use the wind velocity 310º(T)/45 kt. For OAT, the ISA temperature at 18 000 ft is 15 - 2(18) = -21ºC, and the OAT is ISA +5ºC, so OAT = -16ºC To find the groundspeed, we first needs to calculate the TAS. (We have used a CRP-5 and the wind-down method here) On the computer side, in the air speed window, line up 18 000 ft with the OAT of -16ºC On the computer's inner scale, find the CAS of 280 kt, and read off the uncorrected TAS of 373 kt on the outer scale. As the TAS is over 300 kt, this needs to be corrected. In the COMP. CORR. window, calculate and apply the small correction in the direction of the arrow (only 0.7 divisions). Go back to the CAS of 280 kt on the inner scale, and read off the new TAS of 369 kt on the outer scale. The Groundspeed can be found using the wind side of the computer. Set wind direction 310ºT under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the centre point on the TAS of 369 kt * Mark the wind velocity 45 kt down from the centre point. Initially set the True Track 045°T under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would give 6º drift and a track of 051º, so reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 045º. This occurs at a heading of 038º with 7º Right drift. The groundspeed of this track is approximately 370 kt Therefore the average groundspeed for the climb is 370 kt, closest answer 371 kt. *Note: If your flight computer does not include high speeds, set 269 kt or 169 kt at the center point as TAS (TAS - 100 kt or TAS - 200 kt) and follow the rest of the procedure. At the final Ground Speed result you will need to add the 100 kt or 200 kt that you subtracted from TAS.

content.question:
Determine the Mach number of the aircraft, given:
CAS: 220 kt
OAT: -42° C

content.question: The distance between A and B is 105 NM. At a distance of 15 NM from A the aircraft is 3 NM right of course. To reach destination B, the heading should be altered by…

key_points: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning
If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track
The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good
learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (3/15) x 60 = 12º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (3 / (105 - 15)) x 60 = 2º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 12º + 2º = 14º L The aircraft is right off-track, the aircraft must fly left to regain track.

content.question: Over a period of couple of days it is observed that the duration of the daylight is longer and the sun tends to rise earlier. Time of the year is not close to the equinoxes. Where could this happen?

key_points: The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to its orbital elliptical path around the Sun at an angle of about 66
5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth's equator is 23
5o
learning.explanation: The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to its orbital elliptical path around the Sun at an angle of about 66.5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth's equator is 23.5o. The Sun will be exactly overhead 23.5o N in June, when "the northern hemisphere summer solstice" takes place and we have the longest day. Also, it will be overhead 23.5o S in December, when "the northern hemisphere winter solstice" will take place and we will have the longest night. The latitudes 23.5o N and 23.5o S are called the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn respectively and represent the highest latitudes where the Sun will be directly overhead. The tilt of the Earth's axis is responsible for the longer nights in winter and the longer days in summer. It also means that in extreme northern and southern latitudes, there will be times of the year in winter when the Sun does not rise and times in summer when it does not set. Between the solstices are the Equinoxes, when the Sun is passing over the Equator, where night and day are of equal length. The equinoxes are the times when the relative length of night and day and the elevation of the noon sun, known as the declination of the Sun, are changing at the greatest rate. If you consider the time of sunrise at different points on the Earth's surface, it quickly becomes clear that the Sun rises at different times at different longitudes, because of the rotation of the Earth and different latitudes, because of the tilt of the Earth's axis. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day (except at high latitudes) and both times vary with latitude and time of the year. The reason for the variation of the duration of the daytime and nighttime throughout the year, is the inclination of the Earth's axis of rotation to the ecliptic. At the Equator, the length of the day and night varies very little and then only due to the differences between the mean solar day (which is used for time keeping) and the apparent time kept by the Sun. Hence, at the Equator the sunrise will always be close to 0600 LMT and the sunset close to 1800 LMT. At the spring and autumn equinoxes, the time of sunrise and the time of sunset is approximately the same at all latitudes (within a few minutes of 0600 LMT and 1800 LMT respectively).

learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least

key_points: Lines joining points of equal variation on the Earth's surface are called "isogonals" and can be plotted on a chart

Because the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation changes over time and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect

learning.explanation: Climb Gradient is the ratio of the height gained for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage. Rate of Climb is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the minimum vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Climb = Climb Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a climb gradient of 6.6% and a Groundspeed of 180 kt, the Rate of Climb will be: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = 6.6 % x 180 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 204 ft/min, which is very close to 1 188 ft/min.

content.question: A pilot is flying VFR in VMC at 1 500 ft above ground, passing small separated villages. The pilot chose a church tower in such a village as a turning point for a new course. After completing the turn and flying towards the next waypoint, which is shown on the chart as a framework tower, the pilot is not able to find this tower at the expected time overhead. What is a likely reason for this navigation error?

options.A: The pilot changed course at a wrong village.
options.B: The vertical visibility was not sufficient to recognize the waypoints.
options.C: It is hard to recognize church towers in villages.
options.D: The framework tower is hidden behind buildings of the same height.

key_points: Visual navigation is the use of topographical maps to monitor or fix the aircraft's position
Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart

Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring, where the pilot must be able to visualise the terain and physical features from symbols on the map
learning.explanation: Visual navigation is the use of topographical maps to monitor or fix the aircraft's position. Map reading is the determination of aircraft's position, by matching natural or built-up features with their corresponding symbols on a chart. Map reading actually consists of two related, but different skills: Map to ground navigation for flight monitoring, where the pilot must be able to visualise the terain and physical features from symbols on the map. Ground to map navigation, when the aircraft's position is uncertain, where the ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. The choice of the ground features is critical, as things that show up well on maps do not necessarily show up well from the air. The rule for choosing a ground feature is to find something as unique as possible, such as masts, railways, rivers, bridges, etc. Also, the map to ground technique is recommended to avoid confirmation bias, for instance spotting a tower on the ground and convincing yourself that it is the church tower you would dearly like it to be on the map. For this question, the pilot chose ground features (towers, villages) as turning points, which are identical with many others and can cause confusion to the pilot's flight monitoring. Also, VFR navigation at lower levels, as in our case 1500 ft above ground, restricts the view ahead and around by the next fold of high ground and objects may only appear when you are close to them and when they are not obscured by high ground. Probably, the pilot changed course at a wrong village, because of his/her low cruise altitude and not recommended ground features choice.

learning.explanation: (1) Find out TAS using the flight computer: Use AIR SPEED Window: Align 12°C with pressure altitude of “5” (FL050 approx.); Find CAS “13.5” (135 kt) on the inner scale of the outer ring; Read the corresponding value of approx. 147 kt TAS on the outer scale. (2) Find out Ground Speed using TAS and wind component: Wind component: -8 kt TAS: 147 kt Groundspeed = 147 kt – 8 kt = 139 kt (3) Convert Heading (M) into True Heading using Variation: Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least Magnetic Heading (M) Variation (V) True Heading (T) 313° 12° west 301° (4) Convert Track (M) into True Track using Variation: Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least Magnetic Track (M) Variation (V) True Track (T) 321° 12° west 309° (4) Calculate W/V using the flight computer: Place the centre dot over the TAS 147 kt. content.question: An aircraft flies from A to B, the ground distance is 78 NM. After 48 NM the pilot notices a cross-track error angle of 5° to the right. In order to directly reach point B, by using the “1 in-60” rule, the pilot should change the heading to the left by...

key_points: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 5°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track
To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B
For that, we need to find the distance off-track first
learning.explanation: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 5°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track. To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B. For that, we need to find the distance off-track first. We have been given the Track Angle Error (TKE) of 5º to the right. We can determine the distance off track by applying the following formula: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track 5º = (distance off track × 60) ÷ 48 distance off track = (5º x 48) ÷ 60 = 4 NM The correction to reach B will be: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 30 TKE = 8° ⇒ Turning 5º to the left will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 8° to the left will direct us to "B". 5° + 8° = 13° to the left to go direct to "B".

content.question:
Given:
Track= 355°
TAS = 190 kt
W/V 270°/25 kt
After 30 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 3.5 NM right of track and 4.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position.Calculate the actual wind.

key_points: The aircraft is not in the desired track because the actual wind is different from the forecasted wind
This exercise is asking us to determine the actual wind, and we will solve it using with the flight computer
To determine the actual wind we need the information related to actual path of aircraft over the ground, G/S and actual track and as well the TAS and actual heading information
learning.explanation: The aircraft is not in the desired track because the actual wind is different from the forecasted wind. This exercise is asking us to determine the actual wind, and we will solve it using with the flight computer. To determine the actual wind we need the information related to actual path of aircraft over the ground, G/S and actual track and as well the TAS and actual heading information. Based on the forecasted wind, and using the flight computer we can determine the aircraft planned heading and G/S. Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 190 kt. Mark the wind velocity 25 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 355º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 7ºR drift and a track of 362º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 355º. This occurs at a heading of 348º with 7ºR drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 186 kt. At a ground speed of 186 kt, after 30 min of flight, the distance covered should be 93 NM. However, according to the question text, tha aircraft is 4.5 NM ahead = 97.5 NM. Therefore, the actual ground speed = 97.5 NM x 2 = 195 kt To determine the actual track over the ground, we will calculate the actual TKE and add it to the planned track. TEK = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TEK = ( 3,5 / (93 + 4,5) ) x 60 = 2ºR 2º right means that the actual track of the aircraft over the ground is 355º + 2º = 357º Knowing the GS 195 kt, TAS 190 kt, heading 348º and track 357º, it is possible to determine the actual wind using the flight computer by following the steps below: Determining winds with the flight computer: Set True Heading (348ºT) under "True Index" Place centre dot over TAS (190 kts) Mark the point where drift (9ºR) and GS (195 kt) meet. Rotate the wind computer until mark is below TAS. Check wind direction under "True Index" (253º) Count down from TAS to obtain wind speed (190 - 160 = 30 kt) Actual W/V = 253º / 30 kt

content.question: An aircraft following a standard instrument departure procedure, which requires a minimum climb gradient of 6%, climbs with an average TAS of 190 kt and experiences a headwind component of 15 kt. Rate of Climb is the aircraft's vertical speed, the height gained per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady climb, the minimum vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Climb = Climb Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a climb gradient of 6% and a Groundspeed of: TAS - headwind component = 190 kt - 15 kt = 175 kt, the Rate of Climb will be: Rate of Climb (ft/min) = 6 % x 175 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 064 ft/min, which is very close to 1 100 ft/min.

content.question: What is the density altitude, given a pressure altitude of FL55 and a static air temperature of +33°C?

key_points: Note: This should not be a GNAV question
Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam
Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam
learning.explanation: Note: This should not be a GNAV question. Density altitude is not particularly important to GNAV specifically, and calculating it is not part of the GNAV learning objectives, so you should appeal this question if you see it in a GNAV exam. Feedback from one authority shows that has been seen in this exam. Density altitude is a measure of the environmental air density, in comparison to where you would find that same density in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), so you end up with an altitude measurement. A high density altitude means low air density, and a low density altitude means high air density (what you would get at low-level). Density altitude can be calculated in 2 main ways, by flight computer or by mathematical calculation. By flight computer (CRP-5) it is relatively simple, in the "AIR SPEED" window, line up the pressure altitude with the OAT, and read off the density altitude in the "DENSITY ALTITUDE" window (x1000 ft). In this case, you get just under 9000 ft, but this is not the most accurate measurement in the world. We could show a picture in the annex, but flight computers are each very slightly different, so different answers could easily be found on different computers. By mathematical calculation, you take the pressure altitude, and adjust it for temperature by 120 ft per °C different from ISA. As high temperature is lower density, this means that higher than ISA temperature means a higher density altitude, and lower than ISA temperature means a lower density altitude. ISA temperature at 5500 ft (FL55) is 15 - 2(5.5) = 4°C, so with an OAT of +33°C, we are at ISA +29°C, meaning our density altitude is higher than our pressure altitude. The difference is 120 ft/°C x 29°C = 3480 ft, so the Density altitude is 5500 + 3480 = 8980 ft, closest answer 9000 ft

learning.explanation: The air distance is the distance flown in a given time at a given TAS. TAS is the aircraft’s speed through the atmosphere. The ground distance is the distance covered over the Earth’s surface. Ground speed is the aircraft’s speed over the Earth’s surface, i.e. the resulting speed that the aircraft travels across the Earth’s surface when wind is applied to the TAS. The ground speed is calculated by subtracting a headwind component or adding a tailwind component from TAS: Ground speed = TAS + tailwind component or Ground speed = TAS - headwind component Therefore, with a headwind, air distance is greater than ground distance.

The True course in the flight log is 270°, the forecast wind is 045°T/15 kt and the TAS is 150 kt. After 15 minutes of flying with the planned TAS and TH the aircraft is 2 NM north of the intended track and 2.5 NM ahead of the dead reckoning position.

Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 150 kt. Mark the wind velocity 15 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 4ºL drift and a track of 266º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading minus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 274º with 4ºL drift. The groundspeed for this track is approximately 160 kt. It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 GS = 160 kts Planned track distance flown = 160 x 15’ = 40 NM => This distance is based on the forecast wind, but the exercise states that the aircraft is 2.5 ahead of the dead reckoning position, actual position = 40 + 2.5 = 42.5 NM. content.question: An aircraft with a constant TAS of 180 kt, initially follows a magnetic track of 250°M, because of a drift 8°L. After turning, it follows a magnetic track of 340°M, because of a drift 8°R. What is the wind velocity and direction (T°), if magnetic variation is 10° East?

key_points: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN
Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good)
When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least)
learning.explanation: Radial is a magnetic bearing extending from a VOR/VORTAC/TACAN. Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). When following a magnetic track of 250°M, its true track is: 250°M + 10°E = 260°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Left, its heading is: 260°T + 8° = 268°T. When following a magnetic track of 340°M, its true track is: 340°M + 10°E = 350°T (Variation East - Magnetic Least). And since it drifts by 8° Right, its heading is: 350°T - 8° = 342°T. A method to assess the wind is to use the drift on different headings, known as multi-drift wind method: Place the centre dot over TAS 180 kt and put true heading 268°T under the True Index. Draw a line down the 8° left drift. Now put the next heading 342°T under the True Index and draw a line down the 8° right drift again. The point where the two drift lines intersect is the end of the wind vector. Rotate the disc until the intersection of the two drift lines is immediately under the centre dot on the 0° drift line. Read off the wind direction below the True Index as 305°T. And the wind speed is the difference between the value under the centre dot (180) and the value under the drift lines intersection (144): 180 kt - 144 kt = 36 kt. Thus, the wind velocity and direction (T°) is 305°/ 36 kt.

key_points: The heights on the glideslope can be calculted using the formula: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Distance to go (ft) / 60

So, solving for Distance to go, we get: Distance to go (ft) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Glidepath angle (o). The aircraft descends from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft, thus the height difference is 3 500 ft. Therefore, the horizontal distance covered during the descent is: Distance to go (ft) = (3 500 ft x 60) / 3° = 70 000 ft or 70 000 ft / 6 080 = 11.51 NM, rounded 12 NM. The aircraft's average Rate of Descent is 750 ft/min, which means that it loses 750 ft in 1 min. Therefore, the aircraft loses 3 500 ft in: 3 500 ft / 750 ft/min = 4.67 minutes or 4 minutes 40 seconds. Finally, the aircraft to reach downwind from cruise altitude 5 500 ft to the traffic pattern altitude 2 000 ft following a 3° glidepath angle, the descent must be initiated at 12 NM prior to downwind, and with a Rate of Descent of 750 ft/min, it will last for 4 minutes 40 seconds.

The deviation experienced is specific to each aircraft and varies with heading and magnetic latitude
The variation with heading occurs because sometimes the resultant aircraft fields will oppose the Earth's field and sometimes reinforce them
learning.explanation: Deviation is called the difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north. The deviation experienced is specific to each aircraft and varies with heading and magnetic latitude. The variation with heading occurs because sometimes the resultant aircraft fields will oppose the Earth's field and sometimes reinforce them. Which heading this occurs on, depends on how the deviating fields are aligned within the aircraft. The variation with magnetic latitude occurs because the horizontal component of the Earth's magnetic field varies in strength depending where it is detected. At the magnetic equator, all the field is in the horizontal component, at the poles the horizontal component is weak to non-existent. Where the horizontal component is weak, the deviating forces are proportionally stronger and therefore the amount of deviation is greater near the poles and correspondingly less at the magnetic equator.

content.question: The distance between geodetic parallels of latitude on the surface of the WGS 84 ellipsoid…

key_points: The Earth is roughly spherical
Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid
You might come across the term "Geoid"
learning.explanation: The Earth is roughly spherical. Because of its spin it is slightly fatter at the equator and slightly flattened at the poles, a shape known as an oblate spheroid or an ellipsoid. You might come across the term "Geoid". In geodesy, a reference ellipsoid is a mathematically defined surface that approximates the geoid. Because of their relative simplicity, reference ellipsoids are used as a preferred surface on which geodetic network computations are performed and point coordinates such as latitude, longitude and elevation are defined. Modern navigation systems, like GPS, ude these reference systems and the most common of these is the World Geodetic System of 1984 or WGS 84, created by the United States military. Geodetic latitude and longitude is used to define a position on the WGS 84 ellipsoid for aviation charts. Geodetic latitude is the angle that a line drawn perpendicular to the surface through a point on a spheroid makes with the equatorial plane (plumb-line on the ellipsoid) and is other than the geocentric (earth centred) latitude. Despite the fact that, in general navigation, we assume that one degree of latitude along a meridian equals to 60 nm. In fact, using a WGS84 ellipsoid, one degree of latitude has a length of 59.7 nm (110.574 km) at the equator and increases progressively with increasing latitude up to 60.3 nm (111.694 km) at the poles.

content.question: Which statement about meridians is correct?

options.A: The plane of a meridian is parallel to the Equator.
options.B: All meridians are parallel to the Greenwich Meridian.
options.C: A meridian and its anti-meridian form a complete great circle.
options.D: A meridian is a complete great circle of 360°.

key_points: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere
All spheres have great circles
If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half
learning.explanation: A great circle is the largest possible circle that can be drawn around a sphere. All spheres have great circles. If you cut a sphere at one of its great circles, you'd cut it exactly in half. A great circle has the same circumference, or outer boundary, and the same centre point as its sphere. The geometry of spheres is useful for mapping the Earth and other planets. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, but it maintains the general shape. All the meridians on Earth are parts great circles. Meridian and its anti meridian for a great circle. Meridians, including the prime meridian, are the north-south lines we use to help describe exactly where we are on the Earth. All these lines of longitude meet at the poles, cutting the Earth neatly in half. The Equator is another of the Earth's great circles. If you were to cut into the Earth right on its Equator, you'd have two equal halves: the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. The Equator is the only east-west line that is a great circle. All other parallels (lines of latitude) get smaller as you get near the poles. Great circles can be found on spheres as big as planets and as small as oranges. If you cut an orange exactly in half, the line you cut is the orange's great circle. And until you eat one or both halves, you have two equal hemispheres of the same orange. Great circles are also useful in planning routes. The shortest path between two points on the surface of a sphere is always a segment of a great circle. Plotting great circles comes in very handy for airplane pilots trying to fly the shortest distance between two points.

content.question: An aircraft following an approach procedure, which requires an approximate descent gradient of 6.6%, descends with an average groundspeed of 185 kt. What is the corresponding vertical speed (ft/min) required during the descent?

learning.explanation: Descent Gradient is the ratio of the loss of height for a given horizontal distance, in the same units of measurement, expressed as a percentage. Rate of Descent is the aircraft's vertical speed, the loss of height per unit of time, usually expressed in feet per minute. Considering an aircraft in a steady descent, the vertical speed in ft/min is given by the formula: Rate of Descent = Descent Gradient(%) x GS x 6080 / 6000. Thus, for a descent gradient of 6.6% and a Groundspeed of 185 kt, the Rate of Descent will be: Rate of Descent (ft/min) = 6.6 % x 185 kt x 6080 / 6000 = 1 237 ft/min, which is very close to 1 220 ft/min.

content.question: In navigation we assume that the shape of earth is..

key_points: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round
The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator
The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there
learning.explanation: Shape Of the Earth The Earth is almost completely round. The force of gravity would pull the Earth into a perfect sphere shape, but its fast rotation on its axis reduces the effect of gravity on the Equator. The Earth rotates rapidly every 24 h and the surface at the Equator moves os fast that the effect of gravity is reduced there. This reduced gravity causes the land around the Equator to bulge outwards by approximately 21 km, while making the land at the poles appear flattened. The Earth is, therefore, an irregularly shaped ellipsoid, which is flattened at the poles and bulges at the Equator. This is slightly squished shape is called geoid. For most navigational purposes the Earth is assumed to be a perfect sphere (for simplicity).

A pilot intends to fly a route from A to B, covering a distance of 80 NM and departing at 12:15. The flight is planned with a heading of 235°. After 40 NM and at 12:27 the aircraft is crossing a rail line, which runs 90° to the flight track. At 12:37 the pilot should be 1 nm left of the track but s/he is actually 3 NM to the right. What Heading should s/he fly to reach her/his intended destination and what will be the ETA?

key_points: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed
The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM
Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt The off track error of 4 NM (1 NM + 3 NM) is recognized at 12:37
learning.explanation: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed. The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM. Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt The off track error of 4 NM (1 NM + 3 NM) is recognized at 12:37. We need to calculate the distance along track and the TKE (Track Angle Error) at this position. Time from A to railroad track (40 NM) ⇒ 12:27 - 12:15 = 12 min Time from railroad track to 4 NM off track position ⇒ 12:37 - 12:27 = 10 min Time from A to 4 NM off track position ⇒ 12 min + 10 min = 22 min If the aircraft's ground speed is 200 kt, in 22 minutes, it will cover: (200 kt x 22 min) ÷ 60 = 73 NM Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 73 TKE = 3° (approx.) If we alter our heading by 3.3° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: Distance to go = 80 NM - 73 NM = 7 NM TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 7 TKE = 34° (approx.) So turning 3° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 34° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 3° + 34° = 37º (approx.) would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the right, therefore we must fly 37º to the left. Track = 235º - 37º = 198º The aircraft is 80 NM – 73 NM = 7 NM away from the destination. At 200 kt, it will cover 7 NM in 2 minutes. The destination will be reached at 12:37 + 2 min = 12:39

content.question: The circumference of the Earth is approximately...

key_points: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from
The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole
We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM
learning.explanation: The diameter of Earth depends on where you are measuring it from. The Earth is not a perfect sphere, and so it has a different diameter around the equator than it does from pole to pole. We know that at the Equator, 1º Longitude = 1NM. Based on that, the circumference of the Earth may be calculated as follows: Earth circumference at the Equator = 360º x 60 NM = 21 600 NM => 21 600 NM x 1.852 = 40 000 km Circumference = π x diameter (π = 3.14) 40 000 km = π x diameter diameter = 40 000 km ÷ π diameter = 12 732 km Alternatively, you can just remember that the Earth's circumference (the distance all the way around the equator) is approximately 40 000 km (21 600 NM) and its diameter (the distance from one side to the other through Earth's center) is roughly 12 700 km.

content.question:
A pilot is planned to fly a track of 270°(T) towards ZVR VOR. At 10:20 UTC they plot their position and determine that they are on course. At 10:32 UTC, after having travelled for 60 NM, the pilot plots their position again and finds themselves 10 NM off-track towards the south. Given the following information, calculate their average drift from 10:20 UTC to 10:32 UTC.
TAS: 280 kt
Forecast Wind: 150º/30 kt

key_points: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track
Set wind direction to 150º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top
Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt
learning.explanation: Solving from Heading (HDG), knowing WV, TAS and required track. Set wind direction to 150º under the "TRUE HEADING" index at the top. Set the center point on the True Airspeed (TAS) of 280 kt. Mark the wind velocity 30 kt down from the centre point. Initially, set the True Track to 270º under the "TRUE HEADING" index. Note that this heading would result in 5ºR drift and a track of 275º. Reduce the heading value under the index until the heading plus the drift gives a track of 270º. This occurs at a heading of 265º with 5ºR drift. All this means is that, to counteract an expected drift of 5ºR, the aircraft flew a heading of 265º(T). However, after covering a distance of 60 NM, our track error angle is 10º left, meaning our track made good has been 260º (T) Calculating the difference between our heading and the track made good results in 5º to the left (265ºT to 260ºT). The average drift observed from 10:20 UTC to 10:32 UTC amounts to 5º to the left. Note: Drift or drift angle, is the angular difference between the track of the aircraft across and it's heading. Always remember that the drift angle is always measured with reference to the heading.

content.question:
When flying a VFR map-reading exercise, the pilot becomes lost because of isolated patches of fog hindering the ability to accurately pin-point his/her position. Which of the following should the pilot do in this situation ?
1. Maintain visual contact with the ground.
2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance.
3. Fly a series of expanding circles to find a suitable check point.
4. Look at the terrain for hills and valleys or line features such as a motorway, railway, river or coastline.
5. Read the map from map to ground.

key_points: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1
Note the time
learning.explanation: As soon as the position of the aircraft is in doubt or lost, then: 1. Note the time. 2. Communicate, if in contact with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) unit, to request assistance. 3. Consider using any radio-navigation aids that may be available to give position information. 4. If short of fuel or near controlled airspace and not in contact with ATC, set 121.5 MHz and make a PAN call. 5. If that is not necessary, check the directional indicator (DI) and compass are still synchronised and continue to fly straight and level and on route plan heading. Thus, statement 3 is incorrect. 6. Estimate the distance travelled since the last known position. 7. Compare the ground with your estimated position on the map. When the aircraft’s position is uncertain, ground features must be turned into a mentally perceived picture of the map and related to the map symbols. This is “ground to map”. Thus, statement 5 is incorrect. 8. Once the position has been re-established, keep checking the heading and continue the flight by updating the estimated position regularly while looking for unique features such as hills, valleys, lakes, wood, built-up areas, rivers, coastlines, motorways and railways. In all cases, maintain VMC and visual contact with the ground, note the fuel state and try to identify an area suitable for a precautionary landing.

content.question: The pilot of a piston-engined aeroplane, flying a VFR flight and approaching to the last turning point, realizes that he/she is both a few minutes behind schedule and low on fuel. What is the appropriate action that should be taken?

options.A: Make an emergency landing at the nearest suitable field.
options.B: Turn before the scheduled turning point and fly directly to the destination.
options.C: Fly to a lower altitude to increase the TAS and decrease the HWC.
options.D: Orbit and contact ATC to receive further instructions.

key_points: When a pilot realizes that he/she is behind schedule, most probably either a stronger headwind, or less tailwind or just headwind (in case calm wind was expected) is experienced
This situation will decrease the Groundspeed and as a consequence both the required total flight time and the total fuel consumption will increase
The fuel amount to cater for things that don't go to plan, such as stronger headwinds, re-routing, a flight level other than expected, is called "Contingency fuel"
learning.explanation: When a pilot realizes that he/she is behind schedule, most probably either a stronger headwind, or less tailwind or just headwind (in case calm wind was expected) is experienced. This situation will decrease the Groundspeed and as a consequence both the required total flight time and the total fuel consumption will increase. The fuel amount to cater for things that don't go to plan, such as stronger headwinds, re-routing, a flight level other than expected, is called "Contingency fuel". Also, any aircraft must be landed with at least the Final Reserve Fuel in its tanks. If it looks like that it will land with less than Final Reserve Fuel, EU OPS says that the pilot must declare an emergency. But, for this question the Contingency fuel may not be sufficient and so as to avoid any consumption of the Final Reserve Fuel while being still on the air before landing, the best action is to reduce, as much as possible, the remaining ground distance and flight time until the destination, by turning before the scheduled turning point and flying directly to the destination, provided that the ATC is informed of the pilot's intentions accordingly and no safety issues emerge. An emergency landing at the nearest suitable field may pose at risk both the passengers and the aircraft and would be recommended in case the remaining fuel was not sufficient to reach at any other suitable airfield. Flying to a lower altitude would decrease the TAS and the Groundspeed, thus the required flight time and fuel to destination would increase. Any orbit would further increase the flight time and total fuel consumption until destination. Further instructions from the ATC should be asked while continuing towards the destination without wasting flight time.

content.question: A pilot has planned a navigation flight for daytime hours, but flies it at night. What is the most significant hazard of this flight?

options.C: Difficulty in identifying landmarks and reference points.
options.D: Increased risk associated with optical obstacles such as tail masts at night compared to daytime.

key_points: While planning a VFR navigation flight for daytime, natural landmarks such as roads, rivers, and towns might be selected to be used as visual cues
However, at night the visibility of these features is reduced or even impossible, making it challenging for the pilots to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references

The limited visibility at night might cause difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points to verify the position of the aircraft and cross-check the aircraft track, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost
learning.explanation: While planning a VFR navigation flight for daytime, natural landmarks such as roads, rivers, and towns might be selected to be used as visual cues. However, at night the visibility of these features is reduced or even impossible, making it challenging for the pilots to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references. The limited visibility at night might cause difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points to verify the position of the aircraft and cross-check the aircraft track, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. Therefore, the difficulty to identify the navigation features at night is the most significant hazard because it directly affects the pilot's ability to navigate safely and accurately during the flight. Tall obstacles at night are properly marked, and can be managed with proper planning, preparation, and adherence to procedures designed for night flying. Note: The difficulty to the pilots in identifying landmarks and reference points is caused due to limited visibility, so the choice 'Limited visibility and off-navigation challenges.' is a hazard but the most significant aspect of limited visibility is the inability to identify the landmarks. This is why the choice 'Difficulty in identifying landmarks and reference points.' is chosen the correct one.

content.question: You are flying a low level VFR flight over a snowy area with no visual checkpoints. What should you do?
