content.question: A pilot has prepared for a VFR flight in daytime. The flight is delayed, and the pilot decides to carry out the flight late at night with clear weather and good visibility forecast. Which of the following is the most significant hazard that the pilot should consider to planning for the night flight?

options.A: Limited visibility of navigation features that were selected for the original plan.
options.B: Increased fatigue and reduced alertness due to the pilot's circadian rhythm and biological factors.
options.C: Difficulty in identifying the airfield by their beacons.
options.D: Greater hazard associated with in obstacles such tall masts at night compared to during the day.

key_points: During the day, the pilot can easily rely on visual cues such as natural landmarks, roads, rivers, and towns to navigate
However, at night, visibility of these navigation features is significantly reduced, making it challenging to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references
Without adequate visual references, the pilot may have difficulty maintaining situational awareness and staying on course, increasing the risk of getting lost or deviating from the intended route
learning.explanation: During the day, the pilot can easily rely on visual cues such as natural landmarks, roads, rivers, and towns to navigate. However, at night, visibility of these navigation features is significantly reduced, making it challenging to follow the original flight plan based on daytime visual references. Without adequate visual references, the pilot may have difficulty maintaining situational awareness and staying on course, increasing the risk of getting lost or deviating from the intended route. At night, you can see illuminated objects only, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. The other options mentioned are also important considerations for night VFR flights, but limited visibility of navigation features is the most significant hazard because it directly affects the pilot's ability to navigate safely and accurately during the flight. Tall obstacles at night are properly marked, and can be managed with proper planning, preparation, and adherence to procedures designed for night flying.

content.question: Which one of the following VFR navigation techniques provides to a pilot the maximum amount of time to check for other traffic and also maintain a good situational awareness?

options.A: Plan to fly from point to point as identified on the map and then on the ground.
options.B: Keep a continuous update of the position by looking within a short distance of the aircraft.
options.C: Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track.
options.D: Delay any aircraft system checks until the aircraft is turned onto a new heading.

key_points: For this question, examine each statement carefully: "Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track

" - CORRECT: A pilot to both maximize the available time for checking the other traffic or obstacles and maintain a good situation awareness, he/she has to look for a distant and prominent visual reference landmark along the route (such as a big lake), instead of a small and close to him/her landmarks (such as a village)

In this case, each time the pilot looks around for other traffic, can easily identify the distant and prominent landmark at any time, thus spending more time for the other traffic than looking for the same landmark each time he/she takes his/her eyes off it
learning.explanation: For this question, examine each statement carefully: "Identify a feature to be used for guidance as far as possible down the planned track." - CORRECT: A pilot to both maximize the available time for checking the other traffic or obstacles and maintain a good situation awareness, he/she has to look for a distant and prominent visual reference landmark along the route (such as a big lake), instead of a small and close to him/her landmarks (such as a village). In this case, each time the pilot looks around for other traffic, can easily identify the distant and prominent landmark at any time, thus spending more time for the other traffic than looking for the same landmark each time he/she takes his/her eyes off it. Thus, "Keep a continuous update of the position by looking within a short distance of the aircraft." - Incorrect. The available time for any other activity will be shortened. "Plan to fly from point to point as identified on the map and then on the ground." - Incorrect: The Ground-to-Map VFR technique is more prefferable to the Map-to-Ground. When the pilot first sees the features on the ground and then verifies them on the map, he/she will maximize the time available for any other activity. "Delay any aircraft system checks until the aircraft is turned onto a new heading." - Incorrect. The aircraft system checks must be done as described in each AFM at regular intervals. A delay of the system checks may increase the time available to check for any other traffic, but in this case the pilot may pose the flight at risk by ignoring system instruments and indication lights.

content.question:
Which of the factors named hereafter should be considered by the pilot when selecting landmarks as visual reference points?
1. Possibility of identification
2. Transmitted frequency
3. Visibility
4. Closeness to the track

key_points: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots
Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point
With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdaated technique
learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdaated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid. It is likely that a route from the departure aerodrome directly to the destination will be divided into a number of route segments with the creation of turning points and waypoints. Breaking the route down into route segments brings several advantages: 1. Route segment can be selected to pass near a prominent ground feature, to help the pilot fly on track. 2. Shorter route segments minimize off-track errors by reducing the time allowed for them to develop. 3. High terrain or significant obstructions like telecommunication masts can be avoided. Really important in poor visibility conditions. Choose compact ground features as turning points and waypoints to ensure that routes are flown with precision. Large build up areas make poor turning points because of their size.

content.question: What is the greatest potential threat for VFR navigation at night?

options.B: Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness.
options.C: The aircraft height during an approach can be easily misjudged due to insufficient external visual cues.
options.D: It is difficult to determine the flight direction of other aircraft unless their landing lights are on.

key_points: Night flying is slightly different to daytime navigation

The so called “black-hole effect” also influences judgement, particularly distance estimation
learning.explanation: Night flying is slightly different to daytime navigation. The pilot can see illuminated objects only, thus there is a danger of flying into terrain in the case of being lost. The so called “black-hole effect” also influences judgement, particularly distance estimation. The black hole illusion occurs when flying over featureless terrain, approaching an airfield at night over water, jungle or desert. This illusion might fool the pilots into thinking they are higher than they actually are, causing them to fly dangerously low approaches - the aircraft may touch down short of the runway. "Exposure to red light can cause the eyes to lose dark adaptation and may cause temporary blindness." Incorrect. Rod cells, which allow you to see at night, incorporate a light-sensitive protein - rhodopsin. Red light breaks down rhodopsin more slowly. "It is difficult to determine the flight direction of other aircraft unless their landing lights are on." Incorrect. Navigation lights aid the determination of the flight direction of other traffic. "When external lighting provides good visual cues, flying by cross-reference to instruments may cause spatial disorientation." Incorrect. Especially at night, cross-checking the flight instruments is extremely important.

learning.explanation: When a magnetic needle is influenced only by the Earth’s magnetic field, it points to magnetic north. But, if the compass is installed in an aircraft, the Earth's magnetic field will be distorted by the metal and the electrical equipment around it and the needle now deviates slightly from magnetic north, indicating a direction of 000°, known as compass north. Deviation varies with magnetic latitude, aircraft heading and changes in aircraft electronic equipment. The difference between the direction of magnetic north and that of compass north is called "deviation". Deviation is measured in degrees and is described as "East" (+) or "West" (-). To determine whether the deviation should be added or subtracted, use the rhyme: “Deviation East - Compass Least“ “Deviation West - Compass Best“ According to the figure’s compass deviation card, to fly a magnetic heading of 300°, the aircraft must steer to a compass heading of 298°. content.question: An aircraft departs point A, intending to fly direct to point B, 140 NM away. After flying 18 minutes or 41 NM, the aircraft is 7 NM left of track.To regain the intended track in an equal amount of time, the heading of the aircraft must be changed:

learning.explanation: It is normal during flight that the track over the ground is different from the desired trajectory defined during planning. If this is the case, some heading corrections should be made so that we can return to the track. The track you want to fly is the planned track, and the track you actually make over the ground is the track made good. The difference between them is called track error (TE). The angle at which we want to close to come back to the planned track is the closing angle (CA). The CA will depend how much further we want to rejoin the planned track. The 1 in 60 rule can be used to calculate the TE and the CA. TE = (distance off-track/planned track distance flown) x 60 TE = (7/41) x 60 = 10º The same 1 in 60 rule can be applied to calculate the CA. CA = (distance off-track/distance at which we want to rejoin track) x 60 CA = (7/41) x 60 = 10º With both TE and CA, we can determine by how much heading change we should apply to regain track: Heading change = TE + CA = 10º + 10º = 20º R The aircraft is left off-track, the aircraft must fly right to regain track.

key_points: MAGNETIC VARIATION The earth behaves as though a huge permanent magnet were situated near the centre producing a magnetic field over the surface

The poles of this hypothetical earth-magnet do not lie on the earth’s spin axis, this lack of symmetry giving rise to magnetic variation - the angular difference between the True North (TN) and the Magnetic North (MN)

learning.explanation: MAGNETIC VARIATION The earth behaves as though a huge permanent magnet were situated near the centre producing a magnetic field over the surface. The poles of this hypothetical earth-magnet do not lie on the earth’s spin axis, this lack of symmetry giving rise to magnetic variation - the angular difference between the True North (TN) and the Magnetic North (MN). Variation is designated west or east depending on whether the magnetic pole lies to the west or to the east of true north: - If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. - If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least COMPASS DEVIATION Magnetic material and electrical circuits surround the flight deck that influence the Earth’s magnetic field and cause the compass needle to deflect away from the local magnetic meridian. This is known as compass deviation and can result in deviation either east or west of magnetic north by an amount, which depends on the aeroplane’s heading and latitude. Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least Any deviation can be analysed and resolved into components acting along the aeroplane’s major axes. The causes of the deviation are analysed and corrected for by carrying out a compass swing, although some residual deviation remains, and recording them on a deviation card. To obtain a True Heading from the Compass Heading: Use the acronym C-D-M-V-T, and replace the values you are given in the question: From left to right, magnetic deviation W is subtracted from Compass Heading to get Magnetic Heading and magnetic variation E is added to Compass Heading to get Magnetic Heading. Wind correction angle (WCA) is the correction that has to be made to counteract for the drift, because of the wind, so as to follow the desired track. WCA is of equal amount with the drift, but it has opposite direction. For example, when drift is 4oL, the WCA that must be made is 4oR. key_points: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole
The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero
Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing
learning.explanation: The poles of the Earth's magnetic field are close to the geographic poles, which lie on the axis of the Earth's rotation, but not coincident, so that a compass pointing to magnetic north will not point exactly at the geographic north pole. The angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian, or the difference between the true north and the magnetic north, is called variation and varies between 180o and zero. Due to the dynamic nature of the earth’s interior, the magnetic field is constantly changing. Since, the Earth's magnetic pole is slowly moving around, the variation increases or decreases annually and therefore the date of any map showing variation is important, because if it is an old map, its variations will be incorrect. The pilots should always fly with the most up-to-date chart for flight safety reasons. If the chart is republished at frequent intervals, the variation should be comparatively recent as well.

learning.explanation: In navigation, dead reckoning is the process of calculating one's current position by using a previously determined position, or fix, and advancing that position based upon known or estimated speeds over elapsed time and course. The corresponding term in biology, used to describe the processes by which animals update their estimates of position or heading, is path integration. Dead reckoning is subject to cumulative errors. Advances in navigational aids that give accurate information on position, in particular satellite navigation using the Global Positioning System, have made simple dead reckoning by humans obsolete for most purposes. However, inertial navigation systems, which provide very accurate directional information, use dead reckoning and are very widely applied. By analogy with their navigational use, the words dead reckoning are also used to mean the process of estimating the value of any variable quantity by using an earlier value and adding whatever changes have occurred in the meantime. Often, this usage implies that the changes are not known accurately. The earlier value and the changes may be measured or calculated quantities. Accuracy of DR depends on many factors: 1- Time since last position update. 2- Meteorological accuracy of the forecasted wind. 3- Accuracy of heading and speed (GS) flown. 4- Knowledge of pilots in Navigation.

Variation can also be described as "+" or "-", instead of East or West correspondingly. If you are given a variation this way, read "+" as East, "-" as West and use the following rhyme to determine whether the variation should be added or subtracted: Variation East, Magnetic least. content.question: You are flying from point A to point B, a distance of 75 NM, on a heading of 288°. After 45 NM you have diverged 4° right off track. What heading correction should be made to reach position B?

key_points: Two heading corrections must be made to reach position B: The aircraft have diverged 4o right off track, so the first correction must be a left turn by the same amount of degrees, 4o, to parallel with the desired track, following a heading of: 288° - 4o = 284°
But, after this correction the aircraft will be just following the desired track in parallel and will never reach position B
The distance-off track is required for the second correction, which is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles travelled) = (Degrees to parallel / 60)
learning.explanation: Two heading corrections must be made to reach position B: The aircraft have diverged 4o right off track, so the first correction must be a left turn by the same amount of degrees, 4o, to parallel with the desired track, following a heading of: 288° - 4o = 284°. But, after this correction the aircraft will be just following the desired track in parallel and will never reach position B. The distance-off track is required for the second correction, which is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles travelled) = (Degrees to parallel / 60). Solving for Distance off track we get: Distance off track = Degrees to parallel x Miles travelled / 60 = 4o x 45 NM / 60 = 3 NM. The second correction that must be so as to intercept position B, is given by the 1:60 rule based formula: (Distance off track / Miles to go) = (Degrees to intercept / 60). Solving for Degrees to intercept we get: Degrees to intercept = (Distance off track x 60) / Miles to go = (3 NM x 60) / (75 NM - 45 NM) = 6o left. Thus, the total correction that must be made is: 4o left + 6o left = 10o Left onto 288o - 10o = 278o heading.

content.question:
An aircraft flies over a small lake which is located some degrees to the left of the planned track. Given the following information and using the 1 in 60 rule, what is the drift angle of this aircraft (rounded to the nearest whole degree)?
TAS: 100 kt
Tailwind component: 15 kt
Flight time from previous waypoint: 11 min
Off-track distance between the lake and the track: 2.4 NM

key_points: The aircraft flying with a TAS of 100 kt and experiencing a tailwind of 15 kt, will have a Groundspeed of: TAS + Tailwind component = 100 kt + 15 kt = 115 kt
The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track"
If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM
learning.explanation: The aircraft flying with a TAS of 100 kt and experiencing a tailwind of 15 kt, will have a Groundspeed of: TAS + Tailwind component = 100 kt + 15 kt = 115 kt. The 1:60 rule states that: "For each degree of drift angle you will be one NM off-track having travelled 60 NM along track". If you are only 20 NM along track, every one degree of drift angle relates to one third of a NM. If so, 2 NM off-track must equate to a 6º drift angle and 3 NM off-track must equate to a 9º drift angle. For this question, the aircraft experiences the 2.4 NM off-track distance between the lake and the track, 11 minutes from the previous waypoint. So, the distance from the previous waypoint until the aircraft flies above the small lake is: Distance = GS x Flight time = 115 kt x 11/60 hr = 21 NM. Applying the 1:60 rule, an aircraft which is off-track 2.4 NM after 60 NM, will have a drift angle of 2.4º. Thus, after 21 NM, the aircraft will have a drift angle of: 2.4º x 2.86 (60/21)= 7º (rounded).

content.question: An aircraft is climbing to FL300 in ISA conditions with a constant Mach of 0.60. At the initiation of the climb, the aircraft instruments indicate a TAS of 365 kt and a CAS of 264 kt. While climbing, the pilot checks again the speeds after some time. What will be the indications?

options.A: TAS at 356 kt and CAS at 286 kt.
options.B: TAS at 371 kt and CAS at 286 kt.
options.C: TAS at 371 kt and CAS at 233 kt.
options.D: TAS at 356 kt and CAS at 233 kt.

key_points: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during climb
A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs
CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS
learning.explanation: No calculations are required for this question, because it asks for TAS and CAS “at some point during climb” and not at a specific altitude during climb. A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents, below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During climb with a constant Mach number, both TAS and CAS decrease. Thus, since at the beginning of the descent the instruments' cross-check shows a CAS of 264 kt and a TAS of 365 kt, at a higher altitude during the climb, both TAS and CAS speeds are expected to be lower. Therefore, the option that gives both a CAS less than 264 kt and a TAS less than 365 kt is TAS at 356 kt and CAS at 233 kt.

The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). content.question: An aircraft flies from A to B, the ground distance is 78 NM. After 48 NM the pilot notices a cross-track error angle of 4° to the right. In order to directly reach point B, by using the “1 in-60” rule, the pilot should change the heading to the left by...

key_points: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track
To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B
For that, we need to find the distance off-track first
learning.explanation: By altering the heading towards the original track (to the left) by 4°, the aircraft will fly parallel to the original track. To re-join the original track at A, we must find the track correction to reach B. For that, we need to find the distance off-track first. We have been given the Track Angle Error (TKE) of 4° to the right. We can determine the distance off track by applying the following formula: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track 4° = (distance off track × 60) ÷ 48 distance off track = (4° x 48) ÷ 60 = 3 NM The correction to reach B will be: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 30 TKE = 6° ⇒ Turning 4° to the left will lead us to fly parallel to the original track. Turning an extra 6° to the left will direct us to "B". 4° + 6° = 10° to the left to go direct to "B".

learning.explanation: DEAD RECKONING In navigation, dead reckoning is the process of calculating one's current position by using a previously determined position, or fix, by using estimations of speed and course over elapsed time. Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Accuracy of DR depends on: Time elapsed since last fix; Accuracy of the wind velocity used; Accuracy of headings and airspeeds; Skill and knowledge of the pilot. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. 15625 hours 0

Method 1: The Height difference is: 18 000 ft - 3 000 ft = 15 000 ft The Groundspeed is: TAS + Tailwind component = 130 kt + 30 kt = 160 kt 25 NM / 160 kt = 0.15625 hours 0.15625 hours × 60 minutes/hour ≈ 9.4 minutes 15 000 ft / 9.4 minutes ≈ 1 600 ft/min Method 2: The following formula can be used: Height difference (ft) = Glidepath Angle(o) x Covered Distance (ft) / 60. The Height difference is: 18 000 ft - 3 000 ft = 15 000 ft. So, solving for Glidepath Angle, we get: Glidepath Angle(o) = (Height difference (ft) x 60) / Covered Distance (ft) = 15 000 ft x 60 / (25 x 6080 ) ft = 5.9o. Thus, ROD = (Glide Angle/60) x (Groundspeed/60) x 6080 = (5.9/60) x (160/60) x 6080 = 1 594 ft/min, which is very close to 1 600 ft/min. content.question:
The Earth's spin axis is inclined to the plane of the ecliptic. What effect does that have on the duration of daylight at Cambridge (52°N, 000°E) compared with that at La Palma in the Canary islands (29°N, 018°W) on the same day?
Cambridge will have (1) __ hours of daylight on the 1st July and (2) __ hours of daylight on the 1st January.

key_points: The ecliptic is the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere
It also refers to the plane of this path and the orbit of the Earth around the Sun and the apparent orbit of the Sun around the Earth
The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to this orbital path at an angle of about 66
learning.explanation: The ecliptic is the name given to the apparent path of the Sun on the celestial sphere. It also refers to the plane of this path and the orbit of the Earth around the Sun and the apparent orbit of the Sun around the Earth. The axis of rotation of the Earth is inclined to this orbital path at an angle of about 66.5o, which means that the angle between the plane of ecliptic and the Earth’s equator is 23.5o. When we are at the Equator, the daylight does not vary significantly over the year, whereas if we are near the poles, the difference between summer and winter is very dramatic. When looking at total sunlight received, the poles generally have lower sunlight, because even in their summer, there is much lower land area relative to the equator. The tilt of the Earth of the Earth’s axis also means that in extreme northern and southern latitudes, there will be times of the year in winter when the Sun does not rise and times in summer when it does not set. The time of sunrise and sunset changes very little day by day except at high latitudes. The time of sunrise and sunset varies with latitude and time of year higher latitudes experience longer days in the summer and shorter days in the winter. The reason for the variation of the duration of daylight throughout the year is the inclination of the Earth’s axis of rotation to the ecliptic. Therefore, Cambridge, which has a relatively high latitude (52oN) will have more hours of daylight on the 1st July and fewer hours of daylight on the 1st January.

Track Error Angle (TKE) is the angle from the planned track to the actual track. Don’t confuse Drift with TKE: TKE is NOT drift. "3 NM off-course towards the North" for an eastwards direction means "Distance off-course to the left". The TKE is given by the formula: TKE = (Distance off course x 60) / Distance travelled= (3 NM x 60) / 20NM = 9o Left. So, the Actual track is: 104o(T) - 9oL = 095o(T). Therefore, the aircraft's Drift is: Heading - Actual track = 099o(T) - 095o(T) = 4o Left.

A usefool tool in determining the changing relationship between EAS, CAS, TAS and Mach in climbs and descents below the tropopause, is the ECTM graphs. CAS can be considered to be identical to IAS. The ECTM graphs are used to determine what happens to the other three speeds when climbing or descending, whilst holding one speed constant, by drawing initially the parameter that is to be held constant as a vertical line and drawing, later, connecting lines to the remaining letters. The lines are always in the sequence "ECTM", in the standard atmosphere and the speed held constant is drawn vertically. During climb with a constant CAS, both TAS and Mach speed increase. content.question: A pilot plans to fly from an accurate fix at 22:00z with a heading of 175°. learning.explanation: The aircraft covers the distance of 37 NM, from the fixpoint to an aerodrome, between 22:00 and 22:14, i.e. in 14 minutes. So its actual Groundspeed is: GS = Distance / Time = 37 NM / (14/60) = 158 kt. Thus, it covers the distance of 50 NM from the aerodrome to the turning point in: Time = Distance / GS = 50 NM / 158 = 0.31 hr or 19 min. Therefore, the aircraft's Estimated Time of Arrival at the turning point will be: 22:14 + 19 min = 22:33. But the aircraft is not above overhead the aerodrome as planned, but 5 NM right off it, because the wind is not as forecast. Using your Navigation/Flight computer follow the steps below: Firstly, find the Track Error Angle, which is also the degrees to parallel: Place the distance off track 5 NM (50) over the distance gone 37 NM and read over the 60 marker the degrees to parallel 8.1o (81) on the outer scale. Secondly, find the degrees to intercept at the next turning point: Place the distance off track 5 NM (50) over the distance to go 50 NM and read over the 60 marker the degrees to get back to track at the turning point 6o (60) on the outer scale. Thus, the total correction to the heading must be: 8.1o + 6o = 14.1o. And since the aircraft is off track to the right, the total correction to the heading must be to the left. Therefore, the heading to intercept the turning point must be: 175o - 14.1o = 160.9o, which is close to 161o.

content.question: A flight leg of 90 NM is planned from A to B via an intermediate point C overhead a railway intersection. The planned heading is 037⁰T and the planned GS is 135 kt. After 12 minutes the pilot notices that he/she is 3 NM ahead and 3NM left of the railway intersection, instead of 1 NM right, as expected. Find the required heading to reach at B.

key_points: The planned GS is 135 kt and after 12 min from A the pilot expected to be overhead the railway intersection, point C
Thus, the distance from A to C is: Planned GS / Planned A - C = (135 kt x 12 min) / 60 = 27 NM
But, the aircraft is 3 NM ahead of point C, thus: 27 NM + 3 NM = 30 NM from A
learning.explanation: The planned GS is 135 kt and after 12 min from A the pilot expected to be overhead the railway intersection, point C. Thus, the distance from A to C is: Planned GS / Planned A - C = (135 kt x 12 min) / 60 = 27 NM. But, the aircraft is 3 NM ahead of point C, thus: 27 NM + 3 NM = 30 NM from A. Thus, the remaining distance after C is: 90 NM - 30 NM = 60 NM. The off - course deviation after 30 NM with reference to point C is: 3 NM left + 1 NM right = 4 NM left. Using your Flight/Nav computer, the corrections that must be made to the heading are: Degrees to parallel: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance travelled, 30 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to parallel: 8° (80 ) on the outer scale. Degrees to intercept position B: Align distance off, 4 NM (40) outer scale, with distance to go, 60 NM inner scale. Above the black arrow (60), read the degrees to intercept: 4° (40) on outer scale. Thus, the total heading correction to proceed directly to position B is: 8° + 4° = 12°. And since the deviation is to the left, the heading correction must be to the right. Therefore, the required heading to reach at B is: 037⁰T + 12° = 049⁰T.

The length of a degree of Latitude varies with Latitude - being less than 60 NM at the Equator and increasing towards the Poles

content.question: What scenario will give the greatest difference between nautical air miles and ground miles?

key_points: Nautical Air Miles (NAM) is the air distance flown at a given True Airspeed (TAS) and is given by the formula: NAM = TAS x TIME
Nautical Ground Miles (NGM) is the ground distance covered over the Earth's surface at a given Groundspeed (GS) and is given by the formula: NGM = GS x TIME
The air distance (NAM) is equal to the ground distance (NGM) in nil wind conditions
learning.explanation: Nautical Air Miles (NAM) is the air distance flown at a given True Airspeed (TAS) and is given by the formula: NAM = TAS x TIME. Nautical Ground Miles (NGM) is the ground distance covered over the Earth's surface at a given Groundspeed (GS) and is given by the formula: NGM = GS x TIME. The air distance (NAM) is equal to the ground distance (NGM) in nil wind conditions. It is important to note that, as altitude increases, the air distance increases and so does the difference between the air distance and the ground distance - this is due to the curvature of the Earth. The headwind or tailwind component, when applied to the TAS, will give the GS: GS = TAS +/- Tailwind/Headwind. NAM - NGM is greatest when there is a headwind.

The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component
learning.explanation: Wind directions True or Magnetic? Any written meteorological information written (TAF, METAR, SIGMET, etc) will be given in true direction. Any information (ATIS, ATC) given to help pilot to line up the aircraft with runway for take-off or landing is magnetic, because runways directions are always magnetic. The wind velocity is made of two components, one acting along the runway called the headwind component, and the other acting across the runway called the crosswind component. It is possible to calculate the crosswind component taking the sine and the cosine of the relative bearing between the runway and the wind direction. Head/Tail wind component = Wind Speed x cosine (Relative Bearing) Crosswind component = Wind Speed x sine (Relative Bearing) Crosswind component = 30 x sine (227 - 180) = 22 kts

key_points: To determine the True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY at 1003 UTC, we can utilize the following equation: True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY (at 1003 UTC) = Relative Bearing of the Locator (at 1003 UTC) + True Heading Given: Relative Bearing of the Locator PY (at 1 003 UTC) = 266º
Therefore, we need to calculate the True Heading
To calculate the True Heading, both the Track and the Wind Direction must be referenced to the same North (either True or Magnetic)
learning.explanation: To determine the True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY at 1003 UTC, we can utilize the following equation: True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY (at 1003 UTC) = Relative Bearing of the Locator (at 1003 UTC) + True Heading Given: Relative Bearing of the Locator PY (at 1 003 UTC) = 266º. Therefore, we need to calculate the True Heading. To calculate the True Heading, both the Track and the Wind Direction must be referenced to the same North (either True or Magnetic). We will be converting the Track from Magnetic to True. By considering the provided magnetic variation: Variation = 5º W ⇒ Variation West, Magnetic Best ⇒ True Track = Magnetic Track - 005º = 007º - 005º = 002º. Given that True Track = 002º, TAS = 445 kt, and W/V: 050º/40 kt, we can use a flight computer to determine the true heading: Rotate the window disc until the True Wind Direction (050º) aligns below the TRUE HEADING index on the fixed scale. Commencing from the center dot, draw an upward line along the centerline, with a length equivalent to the Wind Velocity (40 kt) - if you use TAS as reference, mark wind speed up from 445 kt, 485 kt. Rotate the window disc until the True Track (002º) falls below the TRUE HEADING index on the fixed scale. Shift the slide until the center dot aligns with the arc corresponding to the True Airspeed (445 kt). Wind correction angle reads between centre line and Wind speed Mark => 4°R. 4ºR WCA means that the aircraft is experiencing a 4ºL drift. Therefore, Heading = Track + drift = 002°+ 004°= 006° Finally, applying the relationship above, we obtain: True Bearing from the aircraft to the Locator PY (at 1 003 UTC) = 266º + 006º = 272º.

content.question: An aircraft departs point A (26°06'N,004°11'E) and flies directly south for 500 NM to point B. From point B, the aircraft flies directly east for 500 NM to point C. The coordinates of point C are…

key_points: The aircraft initially flies south, so it flies along the meridian 004°11'E
Along a meridian "1 minute of latitude equals to 1 NM"
Thus, a distance of 500 NM along a meridian corresponds to 500' change of latitude or 8° 20'
learning.explanation: The aircraft initially flies south, so it flies along the meridian 004°11'E. Along a meridian "1 minute of latitude equals to 1 NM". Thus, a distance of 500 NM along a meridian corresponds to 500' change of latitude or 8° 20'. Therefore, as it flies south on the northern hemisphere, its latitude will decrease, provided that it does not cross the Equator. Its new latitude at B point, after 500 NM south off A point, will be: 26°06'N - 8° 20' = 17°46'N. After B point, the aircraft continues eastwards (i.e. along the same parallel of latitude) for 500 NM along the 17°46'N parallel of latitude. The distance along a parallel of latitude is called "Departure" and is given by the formula: Departure(NM) = Change of Longitude(min) x cos Lat. Solving for Change of Longitude we get: Change of Longitude(min) = Departure(NM) / cos Lat = 500 NM / cos 17°46' = 525 or 8° 45'. content.question: The inclination of the Earth's spin axis in relation to the plane of rotation around the Sun is the cause of the variable amount of (1) _____ and the changing duration of (2) _____ throughout the year at mid and high latitudes.

key_points: Insolation is a measure of solar radiation energy received on a given surface area in a given time
Solar energy is created at the core of the Sun and hits the Earth with an intensity depending on its angle of arrival

The angle of arrival at any point, as a result of the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation, is dependent on its latitude, the season, as the Earth axis tilts in relation to the Sun and the time of day
learning.explanation: Insolation is a measure of solar radiation energy received on a given surface area in a given time. Solar energy is created at the core of the Sun and hits the Earth with an intensity depending on its angle of arrival. The angle of arrival at any point, as a result of the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation, is dependent on its latitude, the season, as the Earth axis tilts in relation to the Sun and the time of day. Also, the Earth's axis inclination in relation to the plane of rotation around the Sun, is responsible for the changing duration of the daylight throughout the year at mid and high latitudes. When the northern hemisphere is tilted most towards the Sun, it experiences northern hemisphere summer, when it tilts most away, it experiences northern hemisphere winter, but southern hemisphere summer. The tilt of the Earth’s axis also accounts for longer nights in winter and longer days in summer.

content.question: An aircraft is flying at a pressure altitude of 10 000 feet in conditions where the temperature is -15°C (ISA). If the recorded ground speed is 485 knots and there is a headwind component of 25 knots, what is the True Airspeed (TAS) of the aircraft?

key_points: Learning Objectives 061
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 061.01.05.04.02: Apply HWC and TWC to determine GS from TAS and vice versa. The question provides a lot of data, but to find the True Airspeed (TAS), we only need the Ground Speed (GS) and the wind component. With a headwind, the TAS is higher than the GS because the wind is slowing you down. Therefore, you add the headwind component to the GS. With a tailwind, the TAS is lower than the GS because the wind is pushing you faster. Therefore, you subtract the tailwind component from the GS. Here's the formula to calculate TAS: TAS = GS ± Headwind/Tailwind Component - Use the plus sign if it’s a headwind (wind blowing against the direction of travel). - Use the minus sign if it’s a tailwind (wind blowing in the same direction as travel). Given: Ground Speed (GS) = 485 knots Headwind Component = 25 knots Since it's a headwind, you add the headwind component to the ground speed to find the TAS. TAS = GS + Headwind Component TAS = 485 kt + 25 kt TAS = 510 kt

Therefore, its actual fuel consumption will be: 142.8 kg/hr - 134.7 kg/hr = 8.1 kg/hr higher than planned.

Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 35 TKE = 5° If we alter our heading by 5° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 15 TKE = 12º So turning 5° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 12° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 5° + 12° = 17º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track).

To re-join the original track at C, we must find the track correction to reach C: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (3 × 60) ÷ 45 TKE = 4° => Turning 4º to the right will lead us to fly parallel to the original track

content.question: An aircraft's compass reads 002°. The deviation card shows 1°W on northerly headings and the variation is 5°W. What is the aircraft's true heading?

key_points: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T
In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole
The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located
learning.explanation: True Direction, the North Pole is taken as a geographic reference and is assigned an angular value of 000º T or 360º T. In most light aircraft True directions aren’t the most precise because the airplanes aren’t equipped with instruments that will align itself with the True North Pole. The primary source for directions inside a cockpit is the magnetic compass and he will align itself with the Magnetic North Pole and not with the True North Pole, those are not co-located. Magnetic Direction, have as reference the Magnetic North Pole and is assigned an angular value of 000º M or 360º M. Variation is the angle between the True and Magnetic North and is assigned in degrees East or West of the True North. If the Magnetic North is west of the True North, westerly variation, the magnetic direction will have a higher angular value than the true direction. If the Magnetic North is east of the True North, easterly variation, the magnetic direction will have a lower angular value than the true direction. Variation (-) West – Magnetic Best Variation (+) East – Magnetic Least The utility of a magnetic compass on the aircraft will depend on the accuracy of its response to the magnetic field of the earth. The metallic structure of the airplane, its engine and equipment can affect the accuracy of the compass, an effect called the compass deviation. Compass deviation is defined by the number of degrees by which unwanted magnetic fields deflect the compass from magnetic north indication (desired indication). Deviation (-) West – Compass Best Deviation (+) East – Compass Least The relationship between the different directions can be expressed by the following table: True Heading (T) Variation (V) Magnetic Heading (M) Deviation (D) Compass Heading (C) 356º 5ºW 001º 1ºW 002º Note: The TVMDC table can be used to relate both Heading directions or track directions.

learning.explanation: Drift is the angle difference from the aircraft’s heading to its actual track (track made good). content.question: Which combination represents the greatest difference between the air distance and the ground distance for two points?

key_points: In still air conditions and at Sea Level, the air distance between two points is equal to their ground distance
But: Because of the Earth’s ellipsoid shape, with an increase in altitude, the air distance between the two points becomes progressively greater than their ground distance
Thus, the higher the altitude, the greater the air distance in comparison with the ground distance
learning.explanation: In still air conditions and at Sea Level, the air distance between two points is equal to their ground distance. But: Because of the Earth’s ellipsoid shape, with an increase in altitude, the air distance between the two points becomes progressively greater than their ground distance. Thus, the higher the altitude, the greater the air distance in comparison with the ground distance. When a tailwind or headwind is experienced, the air distance will be affected, while the ground distance between the two points will remain the same. The air distance becomes greater when flying in headwind and less when in tailwind. Therefore, the greatest difference between air distance and ground distance is at high altitude with a headwind, which corresponds to the option FL320 with 10 kts headwind.

learning.explanation: A gradient can be expressed in a number of ways. The simplest is to describe how many units of horizontal distance are required for every unit of height gained or lost. content.question: The pilot of an aircraft during descent with constant CAS of 120 kt, observes a TAS of 135 kt at FL080. What will be the TAS, if he/she checks again the instruments minutes later?

key_points: The dynamic pressure is the basic measure of airspeed in the aircraft
The Airspeed Indicators are calibrated to read corrrectly at Sea Level ISA conditions
At a height the air density reduces and therefore the same dynamic pressure reflects a higher TAS
learning.explanation: The dynamic pressure is the basic measure of airspeed in the aircraft. The Airspeed Indicators are calibrated to read corrrectly at Sea Level ISA conditions. At a height the air density reduces and therefore the same dynamic pressure reflects a higher TAS. The same thing would happen, if the air was warmer than standard. Conversely, at a lower height or in colder air than standard, the same dynamic presssure reflects a lower TAS. This means that at height we have two airspeeds, the CAS based on dynamic pressure and the higher TAS than CAS through the air. As an aircraft descends from one altitude to one other lower with constant CAS, but higher to Sea Level, the TAS will be in both cases higher than the CAS, but the difference between them increases as altitude increases and decreases as altitude decreases, until they become equal at Sea Level in ISA conditions. For this question, the TAS will be always higher than CAS during the descent (thus, 119 kt is excluded), but a few minutes later, after FL080, the TAS will be lower than 135 kt, 131 kt.

content.question: An aircraft navigates from A to B on a planned track of 278° over a distance of 75 NM. At a distance of 45 NM, the pilot notices a cross track error of 4° to the right . In order to arrive in B, the pilot should follow a track of…

We have travelled 45 miles so have 30 miles left to run to B

Track Error Angle = (Cross Track Error / Distance Travelled) x 60 When rearranged, Cross Track Error = (Track Error Angle x Distance Travelled) / 60 Cross Track Error = (4º x 45) / 60 = 3 NM off course This now allows us to calculate our closing angle, so we can track directly to B

Track Error Angle = (Cross Track Error / Distance Travelled) x 60 When rearranged, Cross Track Error = (Track Error Angle x Distance Travelled) / 60 Cross Track Error = (4º x 45) / 60 = 3 NM off course This now allows us to calculate our closing angle, so we can track directly to B. content.question: You depart point A at 12:15 and begin a planned route of 80 NM. Your initial heading is 235º. At 12:27 you pass a rail track crossing your path at 90º after travelling 40 NM. At 12:33 the pilot realizes he/she is 4 NM to the left of the intended track. What heading should you fly to reach your intended destination and what will be your ETA?

key_points: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed
The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM

Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt At 12:33, the aircraft would have covered a further 20 NM: 12:33 – 12:27 = 6 min (200 kt x 6 min) / 60 = 20 NM At 40 NM + 20 NM = 60 NM along the route (12:33), the aircraft is 4 NM to the left of the intended track
learning.explanation: With the information provided by the question text, we can calculate the aircraft’s ground speed. The aircraft departs at 12:15 and we know that at 12:27 (after 12 minutes), the aircraft has covered 40 NM. Ground speed = (40 ÷ 12) x 60 = 200 kt At 12:33, the aircraft would have covered a further 20 NM: 12:33 – 12:27 = 6 min (200 kt x 6 min) / 60 = 20 NM At 40 NM + 20 NM = 60 NM along the route (12:33), the aircraft is 4 NM to the left of the intended track. Calculate the TKE (Track Angle Error) to give us the heading correction in order to parallel our intended track: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance along track TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 60 TKE = 4° If we alter our heading by 4° (towards the original track) we will parallel our original track. In order to re-join the original track, we must calculate the track correction for the distance to go: TKE = (distance off track × 60) ÷ distance to go TKE = (4 × 60) ÷ 20 TKE = 12º So turning 4° will parallel our track, and turning an extra 12° on top of that will direct us to the final destination. Therefore, 4° + 12° = 16º would be the total alteration required (to re-join the original track). The deviation was to the left, therefore we must fly 16º to the right. Track = 235º + 16º = 251º The aircraft 80 NM – 60 NM = 20 NM away from the destination. At 200 kt, it will cover 20 NM in 6 minutes. The destination will be reached at 12:33 + 6 min = 12:39

content.question: Plotting positions in charts by Dead Reckoning (DR) may be required..

options.A: in areas with high densities of airways and navigation aids.
options.B: during a flight over sea using INS/IRS and GPS navigation.
options.C: during a flight with limited equipment and few navigational aids.

key_points: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots
Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point
With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique
learning.explanation: Navigation by Dead Reckoning is part of the basic training for pilots. Based in the calculation of the position of airplane based in the direction and the ground distance traveled from a determined point. With the introduction of modern navigational techniques such as GPS and conventional radio navigational aids, this may seem outdated technique. Reasons for why we continue to teach Dead Reckoning: 1. Creation of a Dead Reckoning encourages the pilot to consider the safest and most economical flightpath, potential threats and eventual consequences of navigational errors. 2. It is an acceptable and approved mean of navigation. Dead Reckoning can be used to navigate under Visual Flight Rules without having to rely on a radio or other navigational aids. 3. It is fail-safe mean of navigation. DR does not rely on any navigational aid, it is therefore a valuable contingency navigation method, even if the the plan is to fly with. Reference to a GPS or other navigation aid.
